title: 115_hr3978
content:
The Act includes various titles such as TRID Improvement, Protection of Source Code, Fostering Innovation, National Securities Exchange Regulatory Parity, and Eliminating Barriers to Jobs for Loan Originators. It also establishes the Securities and Exchange Commission Reserve Fund. The Securities and Exchange Commission Reserve Fund for fiscal year 2018 is limited to $48,000,000. Amendments to mortgage disclosure requirements are included in Title I - TRID Improvement. SEC. 101 of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act is amended to specify itemized actual charges and title insurance premium disclosures. The Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to include procedures for obtaining certain intellectual property related to algorithmic trading source code. The Commission cannot compel a person to produce this intellectual property without issuing a subpoena first. The Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to include procedures for obtaining algorithmic trading source code intellectual property. The Commission cannot compel an investment company or adviser to produce this intellectual property without issuing a subpoena first. The Commission cannot force an investment adviser to provide algorithmic trading source code without issuing a subpoena first. SEC. 301. TEMPORARY EXEMPTION FOR LOW-REVENUE ISSUERS. Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 is amended to provide a temporary exemption for low-revenue issuers meeting specific criteria. This exemption applies to issuers that ceased to be emerging growth companies after five years, had average annual gross revenues of less than $50,000,000, and are not large accelerated filers. The exemption under Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 applies to issuers meeting specific criteria, including having average annual gross revenues below $50,000,000 and not being a large accelerated filer. The exemption expires after the issuer's tenth fiscal year, when gross revenues exceed $50,000,000, or when the issuer becomes a large accelerated filer. The definitions for terms like "average annual gross revenues," "emerging growth company," and "large accelerated filer" are provided in this subsection. SEC. 401. NATIONALLY TRADED SECURITIES EXEMPTION. Section 18(b)(1) of the Securities Act of 1933 is amended to remove subparagraph (A) and make changes to subparagraph (B) regarding securities designated as qualified for trading in the national market system. Subparagraphs (B) and (C) are redesignated as (A) and (B) respectively. SEC. 501. ELIMINATING BARRIERS TO JOBS FOR LOAN ORIGINATORS. Amends the S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 to address employment transition of loan originators. Amends the S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 to allow loan originators to temporarily act in an application State when moving from a depository institution to a non-depository institution, under certain conditions. The S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 allows loan originators to temporarily work in an application State under specific conditions, including not having a felony conviction that would prevent licensure, submitting an application, and being registered in the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System within the past 12 months. The S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 allows State-licensed loan originators to have temporary authority to act as a loan originator in an application State under specific conditions, including application denials, grants of State licenses, or a 120-day period for incomplete applications listed on the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry. The S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 grants State-licensed loan originators temporary authority to act in an application State if they meet specific requirements, including being employed by a State-licensed mortgage company in the application State and having been licensed in a different State within the 30-day period before submitting the required information. The S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 allows State-licensed loan originators temporary authority in an application State under certain conditions. This authority ends when the application is withdrawn, denied, granted a license, or after 120 days if incomplete. Any person employing an individual with temporary authority to act as a loan originator in an application State must comply with federal and state laws as if the individual was a State-licensed loan originator. Individuals with temporary authority engaging in mortgage loan origination activities are also subject to the same requirements. In this section, definitions for "State-licensed mortgage company" and "Application state" are provided. The Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008 is amended to include these definitions in the table of contents. SEC. 502. AMENDMENT TO CIVIL LIABILITY OF THE BUREAU AND OTHER OFFICIALS.

Section 1513 of the S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 is amended to include individuals licensed or registered through the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry. This applies to persons in industries where licensing or registration was required on the enactment date.

SEC. 503. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The title and its amendments will take effect 18 months after the Act's enactment on February 14, 2018. Passed the House of Representatives on February 14, 2018. Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
